The whole objective of drones is non-transparency.

The loss of democracy may be a gradual process of erosion....like torture, the more you do it, the more acceptable it becomes.

The less people think about Guantanamo, the less upsetting it seems.

Drones are so wonderfully clean and clinical...the bodies are left behind and soon out of mind.

Trump says he will do more torture, not less. With leadership like that, soon there will be little cultural resistance left to calling just about all military murder in the national interest!
That doesn't explain things like wedding parties.

Declared war zones? Sorry, the US has not declared war since right after Pearl Harbor. The post 9/11 half measures aren't close to the real deal.

And I'm sure you have proof that civilian casualties are "would be terrorists." The government has provided none to date. Even if they were terrorists, our constitution proscribes summary execution. Due process, speedy trial, the right to confront one's accuser. All the things we disposed of at Guantanamo.

Bhaskar, I agree completely with your second paragraph. There is no legal justification for drone warfare outside actual war zones (not self-declared by Obama). Any purported justification is at the same legal level as the twisted torture memos of the Bush administration--that is, it is fraudulent. Secret "legal" memos that cannot be disclosed also cannot be believed--that is, if we are democracy.

But I cannot agree with your first paragraph. You have no reason to believe those things except claims by our government, which is unwilling and apparently afraid to let anyone see their alleged reasoning.

Our drones generally target terrorist training centers or their meeting cells. Any "civilian" losses are usually other would-be terrorists, their families and supporters. Whether that is collateral damage is debatable.

However, using drones outside of war zones or in clandestine operations is immoral and unconstitutional. Areas where drones are used must be declared war zones, and use of drones must be approved by the Congress. That will set us on a moral high ground to preach and deter other countries and rogue nations from abusing this powerful technology.

My apologies if I seem obtuse, but I cannot find any meaning whatever in your use of the word "battlefield " in this context. Are not New York City, London, Madrid, Paris, Bali et. al. battlefields in a global war of terror?

We complain loudly and bitterly about the very rare terrorist attacks on our soil. But when we kill innocents not on the battlefield, how is that NOT terrorism?
The constitution is very clear about President Obama's "kill list." We do not impose guilt and summarily execute people without due process of law. "Because Obama says so" is woefully short of that standard.

Jennifer Steinhauer's original article was a factual account of Sanders' adroit use of the amendment process in enacting his desired policies.

The post-publication revisions of the piece by Times editors speculated on the probability that Sanders' platform will be passed by Congress should he be elected president. Such speculation belongs on the opinion pages, not in the news pages.

Unfortunately, the Times' news coverage of the Sanders campaign has shown negative bias throughout. Readers and other journalists have noticed. The Times' credibility has been badly undercut.
How about showing that Nation comes first and just not fielding a candidate.  Cancel the convention and the rest of the primaries.
That doesn't explain things like wedding parties.
I only wish I were comfortable in the thought that Trump will lose.  Hillary Clinton, like Romney and Perry, is a recycled reject.

Richard, I'm open to correction but I believe that that one result of ending the Fairness Doctrine was that the networks changed the business model for their news divisions. News was previously a "loss leader" that the networks were required to provide as a public service in exchange for free use of the airwaves.

Once the FD was gone, news as a public service went with it and it became a profit center instead. Now, I know much has changed since then because of cable and the internet, but it seems to me that a precedent was set by that cultural upheaval, and we are paying the price to this day. I'm not saying that road-kill stories would have been absent today, but surely the fascination with them would have been held in check.

For the first six months have the teenager drive you all the places you used to drive her or him. You were driving your child to school and practices anyway. Just do it for six more months with the kid driving. Time with an experienced driver helps a new driver develop traffic awareness.

There's another good side to this. If a child lives a long way from school and has been driven there, when the teen starts driving, time that was used for a bit of extra study or sleep is replaced with the tension of driving in traffic. It's a pain for the adult who has been looking forward to not being a chauffeur, but take over the driving a day or two a week until the teen adjusts to the change.

Great observation that this type of reporting is what we expect from Fox News, not the supposed "paper of record". It's also what we'd expect in a society with no tradition of objectivity in news reporting.

How low the Times has sunk.

"The hawk might pass. It might."

Let's hope it doesn't pass.

While Mr. Kepner is glorifying the father-son baseball tradition, I find it just bizarre that he completely leaves daughters (and perhaps mothers?) out of the story. In 2016? Really?
And I highly doubt that keeping your children out of school and imposing your son on your work colleagues (regardless of how much they say they 'love' him) on a daily basis is something to be emulated. Instead, it's the worst kind of arrogance and parental indulgence.
Big Boohoo. Get a life.

How many of us have made a tenth what LaRoche has made in twelve years? It's easy to take early retirement when you have millions to live on. Lots of families would be ecstatic to live forever on what he made just last year.

Quitting your lavishly paid job because you can't bring your son to work with you? Sounds kinda spoiled, to me.

What is strange is your need to attribute some dysfunction to a highly successful father who is invested in his family and despite a profession that separates men from their wives and children for most of the year, and often requires disruptive moves to new team locations, his career achievements and potential positive impact for a team gave him leverage to have his son with him.  Most fathers use the excuse of work to treat their families like accessories and prefer to hang with the guys playing golf or indulging their drug of choice.  Equally strange is your notion of schools being ideal, nurturing environments for kids.  Must be why we spend billions trying to combat bullying, reduce horrendous drop out rates, fight drug abuse and once or twice a year shake our heads when one of the fun kids comes with an UZI and sprays murder and mayhem.  And that's before actual educational issues such as schools that simply warehouse kids and they come out functionally illiterate.  Majority of comments today reflect men who feel defensive about their sham relationship to their families and feel better twisting a caring father's decision into some dark perversity.  That's truly creepy.
